definition: Academic disciplines that use rigorous mathematical methods and logical reasoning to study abstract structures and quantitative relationships

positive_examples: The professor derived the equation using calculus and differential geometry
Statistical analysis revealed significant correlations in the population data
The mechanical engineer calculated the stress distribution using force diagrams
She proved the theorem through formal mathematical logic
The research used probability theory to model random processes
Classical mechanics describes the motion of objects under various forces
negative_examples: The historian analyzed primary sources from the medieval period
The biologist observed cellular division under the microscope
The psychologist conducted interviews to understand human behavior
The linguist studied the evolution of language families
The anthropologist examined cultural practices in remote villages
The philosopher debated questions about the nature of consciousness
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: NaturalSciences, SocialSciences, Humanities, AppliedSciences
